doc/source/ideas/teapot/compute.rst.message:
Except compute provisioned resources that are direct bare metal as consumption of an entire node don't have to deal with this.

Granted, very broad strokes are being painted with, but many of these decisions come down to how a business deploys infrastructure to meet their business needs or how a business wants to make money, as well as how they want to spend it. I guess I would feel more comfortable if apples were being compared to apples, and oranges to oranges, not an apple to an orange depending on the operator or installer chosen path. Hopefully this makes sense.

IIUC you're saying that users could just use Nova+Ironic and run Kubernetes on it to solve the same problem?
I guess I consider this section more of a "why this design can actually support almost all use cases despite not having VMs at all", not like "why OpenStack is terrible and you should never use it" or whatever. It's comparing to alternate designs for Teapot, not really to OpenStack.

In an apples-to-apples comparison to OpenStack, I think the benefit is "makes it simple to do what you need, by doing only what you need".

author.name: Julia Kreger

doc/source/ideas/teapot/compute.rst.message:
This feels extremely hand-wavey to me, and I wonder if this is actually representative of users and their chosen architectures?

Also, wouldn't security mechanisms be required to help make it more difficult for container escape?
Yeah. I believe having one cluster for managing the control planes of other, close by, user focused clusters is pretty common now.

The economics of GKE/EKS/AKS suggest that they must be doing something like this (either in containers or small VMs). There are entire projects like https://gardener.cloud/ devoted to doing control planes in containers and other work in the pipeline like https://github.com/openshift/hypershift-toolkit - at this point I think it's more or less a mainstream assumption that in the near future any management system for multiple Kubernetes clusters will work like this.

Security mechanisms will absolutely be needed, although exact solutions probably depend on your level of paranoia + whether you are operating it as a fully-managed service. Options include hypervisor isolation (Kata), restricting tenant management planes to a subset of nodes that are locked down (e.g. no connection/route to the provisioning network), or even putting them in a separate cluster.

doc/source/ideas/teapot/compute.rst.message:
I think things like Ceph would toss a wrench into this because (a) the disk needs to be scrubbed clean for data safety reasons (b) a user has to articulate that is what is required instead of the keys rotated on the disk (with actual disk hardware encryption, or are we talking purely about software encryption?

Another question is also what about all of those storage backends/subsystems that don't allow key rotation on the disk because there is no concept of such capabilities to the block device?

The part about disk encryption was added after comments from Michael on earlier patchsets - he included a lot more detail. AIUI yes, what he was talking about requires hardware support, but at least there is a (theoretical) option to eliminate the latency penalty of cleaning when this is available.

Whether pure-software based full disk encryption could be an option in theory (obviously nothing like support for that exists in Ironic now)... I don't know, but it seems at least plausible.

doc/source/ideas/teapot/dns.rst.message: Is this really required? The compute section makes it sound like the tenant can do whatever they want with the baremetal box. VMs, etc.

Users will always get a control plane (running in pods in the management cluster), and if they want to be able to reach it without typing IP addresses (which they do) they'll need a DNS record.

It'd be nice if they could run anything (I'd like for them to be able to run SLURM one day, for example), and I think there are surprisingly few technical barriers to that, but it's not an explicit goal for now.

Another option:
use externalDNS on the tenant cluster using the coredns backend or the native sites dns plugins.

Use a validating webhook to ensure they can only edit their own dns entries. This is easy to write.

And have a simple syncer container running on the tenant mgmt cluster that pulls externalDNS records from the tenant cluster and syncs the objects to the management cluster's tenant namespace. Auth then is k8s to k8s.

I see a bunch of comments elsewhere about ignoring floating IPs. I assume this still applies to whatever external address method we are using?

Also, nit/allocation/allocating/
This may integrate well with cert-manager allowing for getting wildcard certificates to go along with the dns records via lets-encrypt or from any of their other backends.

I know you say below that we don't need designate-sink, but maybe this is a use case for it? I haven't looked into it much since Graham told me most people don't need it...except those implementing crazy ideas. :-)

IIUC it's a thing that listens on the oslo.messaging bus (Ceilometer-style) for events and then pokes records into Designate. That specific implementation sounds like the last thing we want :D but that architectural pattern could be exactly what we want.

Yeah - I would prefer we use the real API if we do use Designate. Sink is useful for edge cases, but something like this could easily sit in the k8s reconciliation loop to add records as needed.

We also have a reverse dns API plugin point that we could use (there is 2 places we can set PTR records - one looks up the floating IPs in neutron, which is pluggable, so we could re-use that logic)
CoreDNS has plugins for all of the other public cloud DNS services, maybe we turn it around and have CoreDNS get its records from Designate rather than Designate sending them to CoreDNS?
Huh, interesting. That would definitely benefit OpenStack users as well.

author.name: Julia Kreger
author.status: On the moon! With a jetpack!

doc/source/ideas/teapot/dns.rst.message: I'm unsure this cloud can be called this based on the way some of this is written, perhaps their "Teapot cloud administrator's"?

This is a comment about OpenStack specifically, since ideally we want whatever work we have to do to benefit both Teapot and OpenStack users.
In this case, Teapot users don't care whether we implement CoreDNS functionality in Designate or Designate functionality in CoreDNS, because in both cases it's internal to the Teapot cloud. But OpenStack users benefit more from implementing Designate functionality in CoreDNS because they can use it even if their OpenStack administrator doesn't.

Now that I've paged this info back in to my brain, I'll make the text less vague.

This is the stateless'ish option, as it can store state directly in k8s objects. So it can be much lighter weight on admins of the system. It does authn well.

It does not have any functionality around authz though. So depending on the needs it may not be sufficient.

I've used all 3, and have thus far had the most luck with Keycloak of late. Thou to date its been the most manual to install. My hope is most of the complexity of Keycloak will be hidden soon becuase of this: https://github.com/keycloak/keycloak-operator
it will have kubernetes native api for managing the clients/scopes/realms/etc so automating it will be significantly easier soon.

I wonder if the keystone client pipeline plugin to the rest services could be replaced with an openid connect plugin so rather then needing all of keycloak, you could stub something in for the other openstack services.
This is a good point that should at least be mentioned as an option. I'll think about that a bit more.
We should not Impose a system, but possibly providing some built in system may make this easier for deployers.
My preference for this would be keystone alright, for this reason.

Are these really restrictions that block the ability to do "Teapot" in the context of OpenStack?
Just like we have multiple services for containers and compute today (nova, ironic, zun, magnum, etc.) could this not be just a new service(s) that extends OpenStack?
There is the "core" service concept where "every OpenStack cloud has nova", but that concept could change right? (I am talking about the trademark/branding requirements and not the base services list)
For OpenStack there still is. But not everything under the umbrella is OpenStack anymore. Kata for example. Is Project Teapot its own thing in the same way Kata is? I'm thinking so.

TBH I think that worrying about branding and governance and stuff is just getting way ahead of ourselves. At the moment I'm only interested in figuring out whether there's a good idea in here somewhere.

I think the kubernetes community is not fully decided that multi-tenancy is out of scope https://github.com/kubernetes/community/tree/master/wg-multitenancy https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/multi-tenancy

I think they mainly decided to repurpose the term to describe a thing k8s could actually do. (The multitenancy SIG does talk about hard multitenancy, but they are nowhere close to doing anything about it afaict.) In reality they decided when they did the initial design IMHO. Multi-tenancy, like security, is not a feature you can just slather on top. It has to be baked in to the design and in k8s it wasn't.

I think we should have a section that defines this.
I.e. It's an API, with "these" reference implementations.
Or something similar. As I read through I feel the scope is unclear. Some are APIs and integration points, some are reference implementations, etc.

This is very good feedback.

I think of it as kind of an integration project more than anything. It'll take stuff that exists as much as possible, fill in the gaps where necessary, and bundle everything up in a consumable way (and test it!). I'm not sure how best to express that.

I don't buy this. Using a base of kubernetes does not mean anything is "easier" in my opinion. Plus most kubernetes deployments rely on the underlying cloud platform, like OpenStack, for some of the deployment "hard parts".

Deploying managed services such as say, a mysql instance, on top of Kubernets is significantly easier then doing so on top of OpenStack. If you deploy teapot, then you have a k8s. I think that's the argument, and I agree with it.

What Kevin said. It's *much* easier.

* You have the operator-sdk right there to manage it. In OpenStack you either have to use Heat (Magnum, Sahara) which is a very very poor substitute for various reasons, or you have to cobble together something out of MySQL and RabbitMQ (Trove). And in either event you have to run the thing on Nova. That's why e.g. Trove is dead even though it's the most-wanted feature of every public cloud (and they want it because users want it).
* There's an excellent chance that somebody else will write and maintain the operator for you and all you need is some glue.
* You may even be able to write the glue only once and connect it to arbitrary operators (so the same very small service could theoretically provide equivalents of Trove, Sahara, Cue, and a hundred other things).
Are you stealing this term from wg-multitenancy? Would be good to redefine it here.
I guess I had just internalised it. I like their definition though.

"hard" multi-tenancy with a definition or pointer to same?  Or: infrastructure multi-tenancy?  Not sure what is right here, K8s has an active multi-tenancy workgroup and Kubecon always has presentations on multi-tenancy, but it ain't what we understand as multi-tenancy coming from OpenStack. So I'm very glad that you lead with this point!  But it may be worth spelling this out a bit for readers who come from a non-IAAS background.
Yeah, I think expanding on the definition (including the Top of Rack switch isolation / non trust of hosts post depolyment / storage isolation) would be good.
I added a short definition in line 60 after earlier feedback, but this is the first place it's mentioned so probably a good idea to move it up here.

where end users can leverage its operator framework to deploy and maintain the service and where they are not required to boot up a VM and be its system administrator just in order to use the service.

doc/source/ideas/teapot/index.rst.message: So this is a direct call out to the compute layer and BMaaS layer. It would be good to delineate the cases instead of assemble them together and indicate that direct usage shall be the same as installation. We know from experience with TripleO, this is not the case because the substrate layer needed always comes with particular architectural requirements, and if we're to avoid the mistakes of the past, we need to ensure we're more prescriptive or better at delineation to help enable self-customization.

The two big lessons for me from TripleO are these:

1. People don't want to manage their data centre like it's a bunch of resources in the cloud. They care very deeply about the individual names and IP addresses of each and every ******* server, because they're physical things in a rack somewhere with blinkenlights that you occasionally have to go find. Nor is the data centre an effectively-infinite pool of resources from which you get to select some; it's very much a fixed pool and you have to manage all of it. The orchestration capabilities in OpenStack are completely inadequate to the task of managing this.
2. TripleO as originally conceived would have used the undercloud only as a bootstrap before eventually pivoting to have the cloud manage itself. If you never get to this point (which TripleO never did) then you end up maintaining double the complexity while losing a lot of the benefits of reusing the same services (e.g. HA).

I think Teapot addresses these pretty well:

1. The orchestration model in Kubernetes is much more powerful (though this makes it easier to shoot yourself in the foot). It manages resources individually instead of in groups, so each one can be a special snowflake. There's some rough edges because k8s wasn't really designed to run on baremetal, but Metal³ will have to deal with them regardless of whether we do Teapot.
2. The installation really can be just bootstrapped, rather than running a second copy in parallel. Both tenant-assigned machines and management cluster machines are managed through the Cluster API in the same way.

I'd be interested to hear what other lessons you learned from TripleO and whether or not you think they're adequately addressed here.

I'd lighten lesson 1 a little and say, while people would want to manage their datacenter like its a bunch of resources in the cloud, the messiness/reality of physical machines gets in the way and those details end up being important after all. IF a solid/reliable way could be found to manage them like a cloud, that would be great. This is one of the things I think K8s does relatively well. By being able to target workload to nodes via labels, you can land particular drivers on particular types of nodes. Deal with some nodes having different types of storage then others, and other such uglies that comes from physical systems. You can remove some of the hard abstractions that happen if you tried just cramming bare metal through a virtualization abstraction. In k8s's api, its not all or nothing like a vm abstraction forces you through. Individual types of holes can be poked in the abstraction that is a pod as needed (hostNetwork=true, hostPID=true, hostPath volumes, etc. But in the end, the whole cluster still kind of acts as a cloud. single pane of glass to manage everything.

As far as I know, tripleo never actually met its goal of seeding either. You should be able to use a minimal operating system to install the final operating system. You never were really able to use tripleo to install tripleo.
running minikube+cluster-api+driver on a laptop should be enough to deploy the management cluster and pivot management to the management cluster, fulfilling the seeding process. The management cluster can then also manage other clusters in a Kubernetes as a Service way.

I strongly agree that the orchestration system in Kubernetes enables this use case where TripeO was hamstrung by lack of functionality in OpenStack's orchestration capabilities. So Teapot would not have the same issues TripeO had.

Here's where I'm going with this...

If you have a public-facing HTTP service, there is literally no reason to use a LoadBalancer service for it. This won't do SSL for you (unless you use some proprietary annotation that only AWS supports) and in the cloud it chews through load balancers (hence $$) like crazy because you get one for every service rather than combining them all into one. Before Ingress existed, there was a reason to do this (hence, the "older" way).

If you have a non-HTTP service then you might be forced to use this (although in practice probably not).

> It's not meant to be the same layer

Isn't this the same thing as saying it's useful for low(er)-level plumbing?

I don't think either of us is mistaken (or at least, we're not thinking inconsistent things ;), it's a matter of finding the right words to communicate it. Totally open to suggestions.
I would not say that Ingress controllers are "beta" any longer. Maybe two years ago.

Check the top of https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/services-networking/ingress/

Things stay in beta for a long time in k8s-land. But I agree with you in principle and that's why I said "nominally".
The api still is beta. they are working on replacing the ingress api with a new api. Though not clear how many years that will take.

One way to help understand the difference between a "service" load balancer and an "ingress" load balancer is to think about it in terms of how they were implemented originally.
A "service" load balancer is essentially a NAT with some basic load balancing features.
An "ingress" load balancer is intended for edge or external load balancing, where you need full L7 load balancing capabilities.
Features for both vary greatly depending on the underlying provider.
Octavia targets the use case that translates best to an "ingress" (full L7 capabilities) type in kubernetes, though it is being used for "service" style use cases (for example in OpenShift).
Yes, that sounds fair. Teapot should provide both, IMO.

Was it a single node by cluster? I thought it was a single node by service. Which means effectively multiple nodes, which sounds less scary that "all the incoming traffic is directed to a single node". I should double check, but maybe rewriting it to "all the incoming traffic for a service is directed to a single node"
I intended it in the sense of per-service, but you're right that this is open to misinterpretation. Will fix, thanks.

Not sure why you have "large amount of east west", do you mean the ARP/NDP, the node that implements the service lb type to the pods, or something else? Please keep in mind there is a "local" service policy, next to the "Cluster" service policy, to reduce it, if necessary.

All traffic comes in to a node from the, uh, let's say North but then has to go out again E/W to get to the service that handles it. Whereas if you e.g. load balance at layer 3 or above then traffic comes in once and arrives straight to the node that will handle it. So the presence of kubeproxy in the path in the L2 solution results in extra E-W traffic.
how much are we talking about here? I am not sure this really has a lot of importance, or rather: this is important to have working ARP/NDP anyway...

Well, you have to run kubeproxy in your cluster. Although I gather these days most people use the implementation based on thousands of iptables rules rather than an actual proxy server. So that's better, but still has a cost.

It also requires fairly high end and specific network hardware. The gear must support ECMP and, to provide persistence, must support consistent hashing in the ECMP implementation. Many of these issues are documented on the metallb "BGP mode" page.
Slightly side note, but this method that metallb is using with BGP is the same method in the Octavia L3 Active/Active specification.

However, OVN had very limited load balancing capabilities:

How would this be different than the existing cloud-controller-manager implementations?
Again, are we proposing a plugin? cloud provider? or new "OpenStack style" API?
Like Octavia provides? grin

How does this scale (you don't want to limit the number of hosts that can run a load balancing engine limit the limitation neutron-lbaas had)? What will schedule and provision these load balancing resources (k8s can't be used due to limitations)?

Infrastructure service scheduling is actually an interesting problem for k8s. Currently it's pushed to the cloud providers. There is opportunity here to bring value.

I don't agree that k8s "can't be used". Ingress controllers like the nginx one use k8s to provision the resources.

What Teapot really brings to the table here is that it can scale itself out by grabbing more hardware when needed.

I think you're not in disagreement. You're just talking about two different sides of the same coin, the user, and the provider. I agree that k8s can be used from a user perspective by asking an ingress. On a provider (infrastructure) perspective, there is indeed an opportunity to bring an abstraction layer on top of either software, or hardware solutions.
Like Octavia provides? grin
Yes, as noted on line 202 ;)

 > balancer APIs endpoints?

No, it's the thing so that when you create an Ingress resource in the tenant cluster, it goes and hits the API that creates a load balancer in the management cluster.

If the API is Octavia then this already exists, but if there's a new k8s-native API (the custom or Ingress-based APIs above) we'd have to build something.

I like this option a lot. Let the admin configure the management cluster with whatever ingress/svc type=loadbalancer driver they want (metallb+nginx-ingress for example) and then the tenants clusters can route through it.

Ack, will fix. Thanks for the correction.

The Octavia "Amphora" driver is implemented with "compute" abstracted to a driver. Currently, merged code, only nova is supported, but we have posted a functional LXC/LXD version as a proof of concept.
So, the Octavia amphora driver is loosely coupled to nova.
This is why we call them Amphora, they can be bare metal, VMs, containers, etc.
Sadly, design issues in the container scheduling systems, for example kubernetes, has limited the ability to use them for load balancing in a way that is reliable.

Yes, this was described below in a later patch (these take a while to write up, lol).

For scheduling in particular, the "simple" statement is that you cannot stop k8s from interrupting user network flows. There is a pile of detail behind that simple statement, but when you go down all of the paths(and api tricks), this is where you land.
If you are doing anything beyond simple short lived HTTP follows (though even these are changing with HTTP/2 and 3), having pods preempted in the middle of a user network flow is not a good thing and a support nightmare.
As mentioned below, there is effort to get these issues fixed (pod priority and preemption for example), but the community is pushing back on the full solution in those as "out of scope".
This is why almost all current load balancing solutions for k8s live outside the k8s scheduler today. Either cloud provided, or bolt-ons like envoy, or rely on outside gear like metallb, vendors, etc.

@johnsom: What's the problem with scheduling? For me, it sounds like these containers or nodes used for software load-balancing should always run an all nodes, making it an installer problem, or a k8s daemonset and hostNetworking (is that a problem, assuming this only runs in the master cluster?). Is that what you're explaining below, or is there something else?

For the abstraction layer/API, I don't see the problem of running this in k8s either.
Will fix.

This is not true either. Again, the amphora driver for Octavia has a networking driver model. Currently we have only released a "neutron" driver, but the code supports alternate networking providers via our networking abstraction layer.
Will fix.

I would note, Octavia is already used as an ingress load balancer for Kubernetes in production at a number of sites. It also powers parts of Red Hat OpenShift when deployed on OpenStack.
Just an (old) example: https://superuser.openstack.org/articles/guide-octavia-ingress-controller-for-kubernetes/

So there are a number of issues we have run into attempting to use kubernetes as the container scheduler for amphora (or any load balancing engine really). This has led those that do "support" load balancing engines with kuberentes to either deploy them outside the kubernetes environment (see the vendor docs as I'm not going to call them out here) or they accept that network flows will be interrupted or incur outages.

1. kubernetes networking typically layers on levels of encapsulation and NAT, all of which significantly impacts performance for network flows.
2. The kubernetes scheduler can and will terminate pods for rescheduling. This will interrupt user network flows for excessive amounts of time and cause user visible traffic errors. There are attempts to address this with the new pod priority and preemption settings, but they still do not guarantee user network flows would not be interrupted.
3. The current CNI options are not "VIP" aware and do not handle IP addresses that can migrate between pods well. This limits the ability to do transparent network flow failovers (I.e. inside the TCP retry window) using techniques like VRRP.
4. The typical container usage is per-process, which complicates load balancer engines that use multiple processes with unix domain sockets for management, HA, and status monitoring.
5. Health monitoring and reacting to those events is not fast enough for infrastructure networking HA.


None of these are impossible, kubernetes just isn't targeting the infrastructure use case yet.

It's not clear to me if the best answer is to build out the "outside" k8s use case, maybe with an independent scheduler or if it is within the scope of k8s to do the development work to resolve these issues.
The trend towards developing out the cloud providers to provide these infrastructure services (including load balancing) points towards these services continuing to be outside the k8s cluster.

So there are some major problems with kubernetes scheduling for Octavia. This has blocked Octavia using it as well as the other load balancing vendors. I will detail those in another comment post as I need to post the above corrections as soon as possible.

> 1. kubernetes networking typically layers on levels of encapsulation and NAT, all of which significantly impacts performance for network flows.

When direct networking is needed, often the option is to use hostNetworking: true on your pods.

> 2. The kubernetes scheduler can and will terminate pods for rescheduling. This will interrupt user network flows for excessive amounts of time and cause user visible traffic errors. There are attempts to address this with the new pod priority and preemption settings, but they still do not guarantee user network flows would not be interrupted.

I've used preStop hooks in the past to ensure proper stream draining before the pod is allowed to completely terminate.

> 3. The current CNI options are not "VIP" aware and do not handle IP addresses that can migrate between pods well. This limits the ability to do transparent network flow failovers (I.e. inside the TCP retry window) using techniques like VRRP.

This also can be done with hostNetworking: true I think.

> 4. The typical container usage is per-process, which complicates load balancer engines that use multiple processes with unix domain sockets for management, HA, and status monitoring.

This is why Pods are the unit of scheduling and not Containers. You can pass unix domain sockets between containers within a pod easily. HA is done with multiple pods but still possible. Status monitoring is often done as a separate sidecar to enable picking the status monitor you wish to use. (prometheus, collectd, etc)

If you still really want a monolithic single container with multiple processes, that still does work too. Its just frowned upon.

5. Health monitoring and reacting to those events is not fast enough for infrastructure networking HA.

I've run keepalived hostNetwork: true for a while. It runs just as well in Kubernetes as installed on the bare host. It was one of the first things we containerized for kolla-kubernetes.

I think everything you want to do can be done without too much effort. It does require using some of the less common features of Kubernetes though, so easy to overlook. One of the common complaints about Kubernetes is the api is huge. But its huge as users have needed to use every feature that's there. Often for use cases like above. :)

Actually, no, with the current Octavia you can lose a VM and maintain the in-progress flow.

Your comment, "Given that it is taking over the world" I think you have a typo, "taking down the world" is probably what you meant. grin

Again, I will mention that most current implementations for the infrastructure level in k8s deployments push the infrastructure needs outside the scheduler. This is especially true of load balancers and includes the examples you provided above.

I am not saying this cannot be solved or blocks the wider vision, I'm just bringing my experience to the conversation. Frankly I really want these issues fixed so we can be done with it. lol

The reality is that most people that start the "load balancers should be running in kubernetes" have never tried it or deployed a sizable k8s cluster in production. We spend hours talking through it at PTGs and end up with "we can do it today, but it will be unreliable and slow providing a poor user experience", "We need to fix these issues in kubernetes", or "It just doesn't make sense to run infrastructure components inside kubernetes".

I'm still confused about the issue here, but I want to learn more.

At the beginning you implied that the issue was that Kubernetes might kill your pod. But now you say that HAProxy in Octavia can maintain flows in the face of that... so clearly the problem isn't that pods might be killed.

Reading your first comment again, it sounds like the actual problem is that it's too slow to fail over? I can see how that could be a potential issue, but it seems to me that it's more an issue that Kubernetes doesn't solve all of the problems for you (as one might naively hope it would), rather than it prevents you solving them at all.

Like, sure Kubernetes's health monitoring is too slow, but Nova gives you nothing! So use whatever you use with Nova instead of relying on Kubernetes to do it.

In the worst case you could stick the same stuff that's currently in your Amphora into a VM Image and run it in KubeVirt with host networking. It's extremely difficult to believe this is worse than Nova, because it's virtually the same thing.

I read through some of your old etherpads like https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/octavia-ptg-rocky and https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/ptq-queens-octavia-kuryr and I get that Kubernetes is not a magic bullet for simplifying Octavia within OpenStack. But the context here is different. If it's theoretically possible to run a software load balancer in this specific scenario (baremetal cluster, separate cluster from tenant workloads, no Nova or Neutron) then we're happy.

Those are obvious answers that everyone has, but they don't actually address the problems and/or make it worse. We have spent a good chuck of time and multiple PTGs talking about this.
None of this is insurmountable as I said, but the current state of k8s layers on the problems, workarounds and fragile hacks to get around it. 
1. Host networking does not magically solve this problem, it pushes the complexity to another layer and you no longer play nice with the rest of the cluster. Same with nodeport. This is why there are attempts at workarounds, like trunking (see kuryr). host/node/etc. all assume you control down to the hardware on each node and ToR switch.
2. The k8s schedule can and does override the preStop. This is advisory, not mandatory: https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/workloads/pods/pod/#termination-of-pods
3. Same comment as 1. In fact, one well known deployment has to allocate double wide subnets to work around this problem.
4. We know very well what "pods" and "sidecars" are. lol. As I said, this system complicates high performing infrastructure systems. Yes, it either has to be done as multiple pods that must be coordinated together (which yes, can communicate over exposed domain sockets). HA via side cars is not a "replacement" by any means. We need to transition live network flows in less than the TCP retry window. Today we do this in around one second, soon less. With tuning (which again makes a lot of assumptions about the level of control over the host, k8s deployment, etc. you are lucky to hit 40 seconds using side cars and k8s health monitoring. Remember, this isn't just starting a "netcat" web server, it requires ports to be attached, etc.
5. See above.

There are a bunch of folks in the network load balancing community trying to influence these APIs, schedulers, and network implementations. The recent addition of the Pod Priority settings is an example of that, but sadly the community would not go far enough to make it completely solve the problem.

On the surface, "containers" are an excellent solution for load balancing engines, but when you get into the actual details it becomes clear that certain schedulers/cluster systems are not ready for this type of workload yet.

My point was if Kubernetes doesn't give you functionality to do something within its featureset, most of the time you can turn off most of Kubernete's control and do it yourself. Is that extra work compared to K8s magically supporting every use case? Of course. But unlike other systems such as Nova, you can escape several layers of abstraction that may get in your way if you need to solve something yourself. This means, within the cluster, it is still possible to solve classes of problems that in other systems could be difficult to impossible.

My assertion is, if you can get a bare metal Linux box to solve the load balancing problem, you can do it in a Kubernetes system. With the majority of namespaces shut off, Kubernetes just becomes a package manager of sorts. A way to help you schedule a program onto a machine but minimally involved once it starts. This is still valuable for sysadmins to help maintain the workload over something like yum/apt/ansible. Versioning of software, dependency isolation, single control plane to manage workload, etc. In my mind the argument to push it to an external set of nodes doesn't make sense.

Is it ideal? No. Is it still worth doing? absolutely. Could it get better in the future? I hope so. While not at the rate I would like, every release gets a little better. :)

> all assume you control down to the hardware on each node and ToR
 > switch.

I have good news for you :)

 > On the surface, "containers" are an excellent solution for load
 > balancing engines, but when you get into the actual details it
 > becomes clear that certain schedulers/cluster systems are not ready
 > for this type of workload yet.

If the hypervisor running your Amphora VM dies then you'll also lose in-progress flows. Isn't the main difference with Kubernetes that it makes it explicit that this might happen and clients will have to deal with it? Given that it is taking over the world apparently without meeting our high standards, perhaps it is our standards that are wrong?

You can easily run all the load balancer pods on nodes that are tagged so that no other workloads get scheduled to them. (With more difficulty, you could even run them in a whole separate cluster.) Kubernetes does reserve the right to evict your pod just for the fun of it, but in practice it's not going to. Who knows, maybe someday someone will implement a load balancer running in KubeVirt so it gets live-migrated around.

I'm just struggling to see this as an obstacle to getting started.
Yeah, we do need [Loadbalancer] support for the beginning, if only to expose Ingresses :)
Yeah, a teapot-ingress-controller could make a lot of this section easier

doc/source/ideas/teapot/networking.rst.message:
This solution is kind of different then wg-multitenancy has been working towards, so its interesting to see.

This type of multitenancy is closer to "kubernetes as a service" then what the wg-multitenancy defines. Not making a judgement call here.

It may leave room for the two groups to collaborate further without stomping on each others toes.

where I see the biggest collaboration opportunity, wg-multitenancy works to define clearly what the various forms of multitenancy are, and work on common api's. I think we should work with them to ensure project teapot's kind of kubernetes as a service model is defined clearly in their docs so everyone can come to a clear understanding on when to use which multitenancy solution, as well as share as much as possible of the user facing api and tooling around it. This will make it substantially easier on users to go from one form of multitenancy to a project teapot system.

> This solution is kind of different then wg-multitenancy has been
 > working towards, so its interesting to see.

Yes, I see that WG's responsibility as multitenancy (in all its forms) within k8s itself; Teapot is coming at it from the layer below and providing a baremetal cloud that takes care of multitenancy from the outside in the same way that other clouds do. It just happens to do it using k8s itself because it's 2020.

One more option. If done with just one flat network, so long as you add a requirement that tenant clusters need to support NetworkPolicies to be secure, you can use that mechanism to enforce some cross tenant security.

For example, I typically setup network policies per namespace that only allows communcations in that namespace and with kube-system but no other namespace:

https://github.com/pnnl-miscscripts/miscscripts/blob/master/charts/charts/tenant-namespace/values.yaml#L22-L37
and 
https://github.com/pnnl-miscscripts/miscscripts/blob/master/charts/charts/tenant-namespace/templates/simple-restricted-networkpolicy.yaml

For some folks, this may be a much lighter weight solution and good enough?
(or similar overlay network technologies like Geneve)
And even larger deployments may use routed spine-and-leaf topologies?

So this implies that ToR will de-encapsulate the frames.
Is the proposal to provide un-encapsulated networks directly to the hardware NICs or to provide a "trunk" interface to the hardware NICs?
Personally I think there is value in providing trunk ports from the ToR to the bare metal NIC(s) to allow flexible/dynamic tenant networking.
For example, the ToR would VTEP de-encapsulate the VXLAN overlay and present the tenant a list of VLANs that are available on their bare metal NIC(s). Bonus points if they can configure which VLAN tags are exposed on which NIC and if one VLAN is untagged.

> So this implies that ToR will de-encapsulate the frames.

Correct.

 > Is the proposal to provide un-encapsulated networks directly to the
 > hardware NICs or to provide a "trunk" interface to the hardware
 > NICs?

That sounds like it should be technically possible. But given that each tenant is in its own isolated network anyway, I'm not sure I see the value. What do you think the use case would be for this?

The only one I can think of is to limit broadcast domains, but I'd expect that the management cluster would split up tenant networks to limit broadcast domains anyway.

For me, the value would be to have a networking component, which connects on the switches, and configure what can pass on the physical port. It means that it can indeed encap/decapsulate the packet if necessary, and/or ensure that the right VLANs are allowed for tenant x, by configuring the port appropriately. This would allow a simple compute configuration (and its connection to the storage), by allowing trunk ports (+lacp for redundancy for example).

However, I think that this could come as an evolution of teapot.

Also, "small" and "large" deployments depends on vlan pruning and the amount of tenants, so it really depends on the use case :) Though, for me, the simpler the better.
This may not be the right word here. Per the teapot compute vision, we don't know if they are running a hypervisor or just containers inside the bare metal host.
This is specifically talking about running k8s in VMs (e.g. on top of OpenStack, where we have Kuryr to avoid this double encapsulation).
This is not true of all overlay implementations.
I don't think this is a correct assumption. I would not make this a general truth. I am not sure this sentence brings anything, so maybe worth removing?

Kubernete's model of having everything flat has worked out pretty well for it. They usually try to solve the security aspect of it at a higher level then raw networking by assuming everything is untrusted at the network level.
I like the approach. Istio is currently rather difficult to install but they are working on an operator that may make that manageable. Maybe Istio may be part of the solution rather than vlans/vxlans.

But specifically for provisioning, maybe we can flatten this out too. I've wondered for a while, is there anything we could do to make it safe to provision over the same network as the rest of the traffic goes on. What this looks like exactly, I'm not exactly sure. Some rough ideas for starting points:
ipxe on a readonly thumbdrive with an https ca pubkey for booting over https and a u2f key if there isn't a tpm to establish node identity?
Both devices are rather cheep these days. Guessing < $25 per node. Probably better yet in bulk. You may be able to even do it with just a rasperry pi zero... $7. :)

Yeah, this takes a bit more effort to set up initially, but may be better in the long run then trying to keep a pure pxe provisioning network safe?
These are typically painfully slow as well.

As are most bios's boot time. :)

I wonder if a hybrid approach may be better. use virtual media to boot ipxe or the like, then netboot the rest over https.

Right, in my previous implementations(pre-OpenStack), after the clean process completes the host is migrated to the provisioning network via the ToR configuration for the appropriate port that has PXE available on it. I also switched the BIOS configuration to allow PXE on clean, and disable it when the hardware is transitioned to the user. However there are use cases where it may be "ok" for the user to provision their own image via PXE.
I think this "teapot" spec should address how an image gets installed on the bare metal host and where the "managed" delineation is in this environment. This has ramifications for how a user would get console access for example.

I think your last point is covered in the compute doc. Essentially metal³ runs in the management cluster, so tenants can specify an image to boot but they don't get any control over the actual booting.

This resolves some of the NAT issues with kubernetes, but can cause problems with scaling, migration, and the "service discovery" concepts of k8s.
Ideally we would introduce a better way.
cluster?
This is talking about managed kubernetes services like EKS; they have an Ingress controller that allows you to set up ELB in the cloud.

Most cases this is handled by the tenant application deployment tool as floating IPs typically live in a different place in the cluster than the load balancer element.
This is less than ideal and something I hope we can improve on here. Especially if we can remove the implementation of floating IPs by using NAT.
This was a design principal in Octavia, that we do not require floating IPs for public addresses, you can use a public IP directly on the VIP.
A limitation in OpenStack is you cannot "reserve" public IP addresses for tenants without using something like a floating IP. Again, room for improvement here.
We should account for not needing floating IPs as well. They are a crutch in some cases, especially in IPv6 deployments.
I agree here. Let's ignore floating IPs. It's 2020.

Yeah, so in the context of OpenStack (and more, but...) a floating IP is a NAT element that sits somewhere in the cloud and does address translation (the NAT part).

Maybe to help you with context, you cannot create an IPv6 floating IP in OpenStack. There is no such thing, mostly because it doesn't make a lot of sense.

IPv4 or IPv6 VIPs that can be assigned to different resources is very valuable in "clouds".

Current kubernetes relies heavily on NAT and the "floating IP" concept (or even floating DNS? lol). This is a performance problem, management headache, and has led to many workarounds (kuryr for example).

My point with my comments is we should avoid NAT in the design and improve IP management through reservations.

If you must have protocol conversion(not by default), then yes, push it to the edge. Load balancers, such as Octavia(grin) are a good choice for this.

We should not force tenants to use NAT (floating IPs) to gain a public address.

OK, thanks, that helps.

I think we are all on the same page - NAT sucks and we want to avoid it altogether by giving everyone publicly-routable IPv6 addresses.

We will still need a way to sell the tenant a public IPv4 address, but we only need to allow them to attach it to their load balancer, and at least in this doc we shouldn't call it a floating IP even though that's how clouds have typically referred to it when they sell you a public IPv4 address, because that's associated with a specific implementation (NAT).

NAT solves one thing I think often gets forgotten.

In cloud technologies, you want to be able to separate stateful from that which is stateless.

In networking, stateful often shows up in two places. Either in DNS or in IP address.

If you have control of DNS, its best to just update your DNS records to point at the new IP address. But DNS sometimes is slow to update and often out of the control of those maintaining the workload. So its often required to keep an IP stable while moving around the workload. In IPv4, NAT often can be part of the solution to that problem.

Can that solution work for IPv6 too? Absolutely. So I think its still probably valuable.

The other option I think is Mobile IPv6, but I'm not sure its required that all IPv6 stacks support it. (Please correct me if I'm wrong.) So maybe supporting NAT'ed IPv6 still makes sense.

Not speaking to what Teapot should choose specifically, but I hear a lot of bad things about NAT, but rarely do I hear someone speak up about addressing this issue.

again in agreement. Let's not count nat into this story. I know it cood look like it's removing a big chunk of the user base, but effectively it's not. IPv6 is a reality, and we have the ingress as abstration for v4.

I'd like to get some clarification on what we're saying here, because cloud networking is not my strong suit. (Before you ask, it's "arguing on the Internet", obviously.).

What lines 130-131 are saying is that we could totally say that tenant clusters are IPv6 only - i.e. NodePort service types only get IPv6 addresses - and that you can only get IPv4 addresses by creating a LoadBalancer Service or an Ingress. (I'm personally in favour of this plan BTW.) I think this is the same as what JP is saying?

But load balancers will also need to be able to get IP (v4 and v6) addresses. For HA they will need to be able to, uh, float between different instances of the load balancer, and in fact a user might sometimes want to move one to a completely different load balancer. Naively one might think of these IPs that float as "floating IPs", but perhaps that's not technically correct?

It's likely that this stuff is not explained clearly enough because I'm not enough of an expert to cut through the fog of terminology (and also because info about floating IPs is awkwardly spread between this page, the load balancing one, and the dns one, since it touches all three). So rewrites are invited :)

I think this implementation of an ingress would be very dependent on what's running on the final compute node, and therefore the CNI plugin will have an impact, don't you think?

Should we establish a first series of recommendations?
If that's the case, shouldn't we think of simplifying further by taking a stance on what's required?

I am not focusing on which service the ingress connects to (as this should be okay using the kubernetes networking model by default).

I am focusing on how the ingress itself is working. Ingress are generally services themselves, to be properly exposed.
All your text is valid.

This triggers a few questions.
Where does the ingress run? Inside the tenant cluster? Inside the management cluster (how many ingresses per tenant?)? From a user perspective, I shouldn't configure my k8s cluster to deploy an nginx ingress with whatever service type to be able to use ingress resources. It should "just work". So it means that the management cluster should deal with providing an ingress controller. Which means having an opinion. That is fine for me, I just want it to be clear. (Or we say "it's out of scope).

If teapot has an official ingress, should we suppose it will run in the tenant cluster itself or not? it doesn't look clear to me. If it runs inside the tenant cluster, aren't you afraid of support cases of breakages due to <ingress controller> not working with <network implemented in the tenant using cni>. 

It's late for me, so maybe these are just mumblings :)

I think it's clearer if you read the whole load balancer page in conjunction with this than it is from this paragraph on its own. In this model you would have an Ingress controller in the tenant that simply proxies the data to a tenant-specific namespace in the management cluster, where *another* Ingress controller (could be nginx, Octavia, HW load balancer...) will do the actual load balancing. Virtual IPs would be handled at this level. The load balancer would connect to the tenant service directly over IPv6.

So short answer to your question is, it runs in the management cluster. Number of Ingresses per tenant will need to be controlled by quota.

Alternatively, of course users are always free to run the nginx Ingress controller or something similar inside their own cluster, but it's up to them to make sure it works with whatever networking they have chosen.

I missed this comment the first time around.

AFAIK it's not dependent on the CNI plugin? An Ingress targets one or more Services (presumably of type NodePort), so if the CNI plugin allows the load balancer to connect to that service then it will work (and if it doesn't then nothing will work). Can you clarify what you mean?

CustomResourceDefinition (CRD)
We should expand the acronyms throughout this document. There are a lot used, some that are domain specific.
Yep good catch. I got better at defining TLAs over time, but this doc was the first one I wrote.

This slightly confuses me. Is "teapot" a specification for a new "OpenStack style" API on top of kubernetes clusters? or is it plugin extensions to a k8s API?
Many of these plugin extensions already exist, like metal^3.
that's my understanding. Isn't that awesome that we reuse instead of rebuild? :)
My reading of it is that project teapot is a reference implementation solving the problems raised in this doc by some custom code, some api's and a lot of existing projects integrated together?
+1 to making a k8s native api. This allows switching out implementations like you mention much easier.
agreed
(or similar overlay networking solutions like Geneve) ?
Didn't know that, thanks.
AFAIK there's ~no hw support for Geneve, so it's a non-starter for bare-metal. Even OVN relies on VxLAN for bare-metal.
And even larger deployments may need routed spine-and-leaf topology solutions?
My intent was just not to preclude, not to advocate spine-leaf as a starting point.

We discussed the possibility of enforcing multi-tenancy through routing alone, but came to the conclusion it is not feasible. Graham can probably explain more convincingly, so I will refrain from making something up ;)

That said, as noted on line 16-18, in a large deployment, not all of a tenant's machines would necessarily end up in the same VxLAN; so at that point it would be a routed network.
Yeap - I was just being extra clear so others can see this discussion as well :)

Well IIUC routed spine-leaf data centre topology doesn't enforce multi-tenancy by routing alone.  vxlan-overlays still encapsulate layer 2 frames in UDP datagrams, but this is scoped to a "leaf" (e.g. rack) and layer 3 subnet-supernet routing is used to stitch these leaves together.  But I'll defer to Graham or Dan or others who know more about this than I do.

It all comes down to scale. Spine and Leaf may be needed in very large deployments, but it can add a lot of complexity (especially early on for us).

When I was thinking about this, I was taking 100 nodes as the upper limit of nodes in a single k8s cluster (I am aware there is "docs" that say you can have more, but from experience, it ends up requiring manual tuning to really work after that). In this case scheduling nodes closer together (physically) can reduce the load on the east - west DC network fabric.

Of course, we shouldn't do anything to preclude this in the future, but the core of this network proposal is "the server gets an untagged network port(s) to send traffic both east west and north south" which means as long as the spine & leaf allows each node to talk to the others over that port, we are OK.
Do you want two different terms for floating IPs in the OpenStack NAT sense and for the virtual IP presented by a load balancer?
Yeah, not sure what to call them - something like "externally routable IP addresses" ? "Public IPs"?
Judging by comments on the previous patch set, apparently I do :D

doc/source/ideas/teapot/networking.rst.message: s/could/should/ although as we've learned in OpenStack, people are super uncomfortable with switch automation.

Network Teams are still typically siloed away from Host Teams. So getting the Network Team to give you enough credentials/access/etc to automate switch management is often a tough sell in a lot of organizations.

One of the lessons I learned from K8s networking though, is sometimes its better to consider solving issues higher up in the network layer cake then at lower levels. Contrast Neutron like l2 software defined networking and K8s's NetworkPolicy and Service Meshes. You can solve a bunch of problems at the l2 layer such as what can talk to what, but you could also solve it higher with NetworkPolicy/ServiceMesh. Its becoming increasingly rare when I actually need a virtual l2 network and NetworkPolicy/ServiceMeshes provide a lot more functionality with less operator complexity like trying to get the Network Team to give access to switches.

I still wonder, is a dedicated network for provisioning really the best solution or can we get creative and come up with something higher up in the network stack that works just as well without the complexity at the Network layer where siloing makes things harder to solve?

"separate network" meaning separate to the provisioning network. So what this is saying is that you could leave the (untagged) provisioning network always connected, but have IPA talk on a separate (tagged) network that only gets connected when the host is not provisioned. Or you could just keep it on the provisioning network and only connect that when the host is not provisioned. So either way, it doesn't allow the baremetal-operator+Ironic subsystem to not care about networking configuration.


I hadn't heard that people are uncomfortable with switch automation, that's interesting. Do you have a sense of what in particular bothers them? I tend to be a bit skeptical of stuff like this because people have a tendency to suddenly not care when an exciting new product comes along that conflicts with their long-held but mostly baseless prejudice against doing some thing.

For example, when we first did Heat, it was a fundamental design tenet that we couldn't use ssh to provision a user's server. Totally unacceptable! People didn't even enable sshd and they never would because it was contrary to their immutable security policies. So we hacked together an agent-based thing (because as we all know, agents are always perfectly secure, except for sshd of course which is extremely dangerous). This was after I moved to OpenStack from another dead end project, where I was brought in after they'd had an intern write an agent that pulled stuff without any particular provision for security and ran it as root... because I guess security policies said no sshd but they didn't say anything about agents with no security provisions at all that were written by random interns.

Anyway, then Ansible came along and everybody loved it and wanted to know why Heat couldn't be more like that.

So yeah, interested to hear specific objections and think about how we can overcome them. But let's not hold up progress unless they're actually right :)

> Network Teams are still typically siloed away from Host Teams. So
 > getting the Network Team to give you enough credentials/access/etc
 > to automate switch management is often a tough sell in a lot of
 > organizations.

I really fear for anyone who is trying to build a private cloud while having two separate teams warring for control over the components *within a rack*.

 > I still wonder, is a dedicated network for provisioning really the
 > best solution or can we get creative and come up with something
 > higher up in the network stack that works just as well without the
 > complexity at the Network layer where siloing makes things harder
 > to solve?

I do like the idea of booting a minimal image with unique creds over virtualmedia, then using that to chain-load over HTTPS or something like that.

That said, the best we can hope to achieve by tweaking the provisioning is to allow the networking part and the provisioning part to operate independently of each other. The whole of Teapot's networking is predicated on being able to control the ToR switch, and that can't be fixed by adding additional layers because tenants want to be able to add their own layers and that's too many layers.

> I really fear for anyone who is trying to build a private cloud

 > components *within a rack*.

doc/source/ideas/teapot/storage.rst.message:
nit:
I think if you clarify this by rephrasing it differently:
- "hyperconverged storage" happens inside the compute cluster, and therefore is out of scope for teapot (you run what you want within the cluster)
- "shared storage pool" is in the scope of teapot.

That's basically what you said here, for the correct reasons explained in this paragraph.
Thanks, always good to hear where things could be clearer. I'll try to rework this a bit.

Yeah, you can't independently scale storage and compute resources.

Also, with hyperconverged storage the life cycle of the compute and storage in a cluster are tightly coupled.  You can't rent compute for a couple days, free it up, and come back two weeks later and pick up the storage it was using.

Perhaps something along these lines:

Cinder is more limited than Manila in the sense that it can only provide 'RWO' (Read/Write One) access to persistent storage to most applications.  Kubernetes volume mounts are generally file based -- Kubernetes creates its own local file system on block devices if it does not discover one there already.  That said, Kubernetes recently added *raw* block mode support, which does support RWX mode for specialized applications that can work with block device offsets rather than file system paths.  Kubevirt in particular is expected to use raw block mode persistent volumes, so this is likely to be a common use case.
As K8s has support for supplying multiple storage types to clusters, I do think including both is useful.

If you remove the nova interaction and the Cinder backup service, Cinder and Manila have similer architectures: an API service, a Scheduler Service, and a Volume/Share service with aync messaging among these via rabbitmq and resource state persistence in a relational database.  I'd expect that the work to leverage an administratively owned relational database running in K8s and the work to replace rabbitmq with json-rpc would be very similar for Cinder and Manila.

Conceptually, this is a good idea, unfortunately right now, with the current implementations, it is not. (secrets are stored un encrypted in etcd, when they get mounted to a Pod, they can exist on disk on the node unencrypted, etc). 

Potentially adding a vault or exposing a multi tenant barbican could help, but that is extra work.

Yeah, was just reading up on that. Agree that it doesn't help very much if the keys are stored in plaintext in the same DB as the encrypted data.

All of the existing KMS providers are for public clouds afaict?
You'd think that Vault would be one of the first ones implemented, but I can only find an archived repo from Oracle with a single commit (code dump). And all of the instructions for running Vault in k8s at all end up using a cloud's key management service for unsealing. It's turtles all the way down.

I'm starting to wonder if we need a separate key management doc, since there literally doesn't seem to be another way to protect secrets without going to public cloud.

Secrets don't have to be stored unencrypted: https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/administer-cluster/encrypt-data/

And they don't have to be mounted in a Pod. In fact we wouldn't want that, because the secret belongs to the tenant and not to the Cinder service. So we'd use the user's token passed to Castellan, and it would make a call to the k8s API, authed via Keystone using that token, instead of using Barbican as the backend.

yeah - to be safe [2] you have to run a KMS provider[1] (otherwise the encrypted secrets are encrypted with a key that is also on the disk), at which point you are running barbican / vault / $HSM anyway 

1 - https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/administer-cluster/kms-provider/

2 - from the page you linked :

> Storing the raw encryption key in the EncryptionConfig only moderately improves your security posture, compared to no encryption. Please use kms provider for additional security. By default, the identity provider is used to protect secrets in etcd, which provides no encryption. EncryptionConfiguration was introduced to encrypt secrets locally, with a locally managed key.

It occurs to me that we may need a brief discussion of Object storage, especially given the emergence of Object Bucket Claims [1] alongside Kubernetes Persistent Volume Claims.  Some observations:

  * Apps running in K8s may use OBCs alongside PVCs
  * These may be fulfilled by Object services running
     - hyperconverged using storage native to physical compute nodes in the cluser
     - provided by the cloud, like Manila or Cinder
     - from a foreign cloud
  * Reasons for having a local cloud-provider option
     - save bandwidth/cost/latency vs foreign cloud
     - scale independently of compute vs hyperconverged
     - independent life-cycle vs hyperconverged: can persist objects even when the compute cluster is spun down so the stored objects can be used later after spinning it back up
     - straightforward object sharing across tenant k8s clusters (just share required secrets)
  * local cloud-provider supplied Object storage service:
    - can be classical Swift or a service (e.g. Ceph RGW) that emulates Swift
    - may use S3 API rather than classical Swift API for ease of OBC integration
    - is integrated with Keystone multitenancy: different tenant K8s clusters get different client credentials for getting and putting objects to the cloud provider object service and objects/buckets within the service are completely segregated by tenant ownership.
     
[1] https://rook.io/docs/rook/v1.1/ceph-object-bucket-claim.html [Note that although OBCs are coming out of Rook, they are not conceived as Rook-specific]
OBC seems interesting - we should defintely track it for teapot

Simply comparing the lengths of these 2 lists seems like it leaves the door open for some interesting corner cases. I wonder if it would make sense to do a deeper set comparison here, asserting that the content of the sets are different based on the subnet UUID's in each set.

There could be others, but the case I'm thinking of is where a subnet is removed and another is added in its place before the agent gets to this line. In that scenario you will need to process a new subnet, but comparing only the length of the old and new lists causes us to miss that.

Yes you are right we should be adding cases for handling, subnet removed and also subnet changes.
Subnet removed and subnet added will be handled in two different transactions when it comes here.
So if we handle each of these cases individually it would be fine.

Makes sense, this is just a nit :)

My comments on PS17 still apply. I think this should be a set operation rather than comparing the length of lists. Comparing the length of the lists is too superficial, what we're really after is whether there are new subnets to process. This condition can evaluate to False simply because the same number of subnets still applies, even though there is a new subnet we need to process. I'm thinking of something along these lines:

old_agent_port_subnets = set(self.agent_gateway_port.get('subnets', []))
new_agent_port_subnets = set(agent_gateway_port.get('subnets', []))

if len(new_agent_port_subnets.difference(old_agent_port_subnets) > 0:
...
...
...

OK, with a second look at this I see what you're saying. I still think a set difference operation to identify new subnets might be a little more clear and allow us to express the same logic with fewer lines of code and if...elif blocks.

The first level of comparision is the size of the subnets, and then we do check if the items in the subnet list that was greater is it still in the old list or not.

tasks/collect.yml.message:
It is well documented that ansible does lazy evaluation of all variables, mainly expanding them as late as possible.

The only reason for using the vars here is to make code
easier to read, and keeping the line under 160 chars.

Initially I just had a single line, w/o vars block but it was too long/hard to read/review.

Splitting it in two phases, sorts this issue, w/o performance issues.

This is not the first place where we did this, in fact I am  not sure even if I was the first in our team to use this trick.

Any var defined in a task is visible only to that task, acting as a "local" var.

The construct may look bit complex but it works and AFAIK is
the only one that merges correctly nested dictionaries. It took a lot of googling to come to it but I am more than
happy to change it with something shorter if that is found.

Its complexity is why I added the two extra comments, that
explain what code does.

This doesn't avoid the race condition.  Took me a while, but I think I have a test showing this.  The test will fail on this code but will pass if this line is changed to 'return'.

That being said, I think return isn't the correct thing to do here. I think we should go ahead and return some kind of 4xx, probably a HTTPConflict with message something like "Image location already in process of being deleted".  (This would distinguish this situation from the 404 being returned at line 377.)

I'll upload the test for us to look at and make sure it's doing what I think it is.

NIT:
sorry for late comment but can we move it at the top before fetching image?
I don't think this is accurate -- the location gets removed from the image object being carried around in memory, but I don't think it actually gets updated in the DB until line 423?

I suggest leaving location.py unchanged and instead catch the glance_store.exceptions.NotFound in this chain of exception handlers.  We are making the inference that since the location existed when we got the image at line 376, but now it cannot be found in the backend, the data must have been deleted by another call.  The location.pop() has raised an exception, so we don't want to call save() at line 423.  (We can't simply remove the location ourselves because location.remove() calls location.pop(), so remove() will also fail with a NotFound.)

I think the right thing to do here is to go ahead and raise webob.exc.HTTPNotFound (so that line 423 is not called).  If I issue 5 DELETE requests on a resource, I'd expect (in the best case) to get one 2xx and four 404s.  So I think we should rely on the call that actually was able to delete the data to complete and return a 204, and this thread here should return a 404 ("Data for image %(id) cannot be found in store %(store_id)") without making any changes to the system.
See my comment on the previous PS.  I think we should reword this to talk about stores and image data.

It was an "outside" comment on the review page:

Reading through the exception responses, I think there is too much "location" talk.  We want users to deal with stores and image data (because we'd like to get to the point eventually where image locations aren't exposed to users at all).  So, for instance, the error message at line 392 should probably read, "Cannot delete image data from the only store containing it.  Consider deleting the image instead."  The message at line 385 should be something like "Cannot delete image data from a store when the image status is %s".

The request we are processing is DELETE /v2/stores/store_id/image_id -- nothing about locations there.

Sorry, went through every previous PS and couldn't find anything here.

Not sure if that would help anyone to move away from the well established "locations" we have been using for years and everyone is familiar with.

Lets see what Abhishek, Sean and others thinks as well. The messages are trivial change to do.

As the title suggests delete image from single store, we should reflect the same from the log/error messages as well. Also for this feature locations are not exposed to end users so it makes more sense to talk about particular image and store.
Same here.
"from the list" (db isn't changed until image.save())

Two things here: (1) I don't think we should expose the exception message to the end user, and (2) we should express this in terms of store and image data for the end user: "The data for image %(id) cannot be deleted from store %(sid) because it is in use"

class InUseByStore(GlanceStoreException):

glance/common/store_utils.py.message: Log only messages should not be translated.

You're passing a tuple here as the first argument instead of a string.  I don't think it will cause an exception, but the message will look weird.

This will work if you unpack the tuple in the call:

  LOG.warn(*msg)

I actually kind of like this pattern, defining the message as a tuple of (str, dict) and then using the * operator to unpack it when sending it to the log.  But that's an optimization you can make (or not) when you clean up that logging in a follow-up patch.  I don't want to hold this patch up.

glance/location.py.message:
I'm worried about a race condition in this function.  The delete_image_location_from_backend() call will take some time, so if we get two DELETE /v2/stores/store_id/image_id close together, they could both hit this code because each of their image proxies will still have the location present in the list.  They hit here and the first one may succeed but the second could get a not found exception from glance_store, and then it will put the location back at line 249 and reraise the exception.

It may not be a problem as long as the location isn't saved back to the DB.  The delete_from_store() code on this patch looks like it would just raise a webob exception and not save, so that seems right, but I think we may need to reassess the exceptions that are being caught in delete_from_store() so that this case doesn't raise a 500.

What ever the end result is 500 is not the right response. I addressed that in the next PS by just passing on store NotFound which addresses both, the race case should one happen and it also addresses a case where say, the store is corrupt and there is no data anymore and we need to get rid of the records in the db.

I'll think about this some more, but this function is weird enough as it is without hiding this exception.  I think we should leave this code the way it is and handle the exception in the calling code.  (I think it will make debugging easier.)

Let's revise the comment to be completely clear why we are doing this (and that we're doing it on purpose!).  Something like:

NOTE(jokke): This can happen if the data was deleted by an operator from the backend, or a race condition from multiple delete-from-store requests.  The old way to deal with this was that the user could just delete the image when the data is gone, but with multi-store, that is no longer a good option.  So we intentionally leave the location popped (in other words, the pop() succeeds) but we also reraise the NotFound so that the calling code knows what happened.

In this case, the request will return a HTTP 410 (Gone) response and the store will no longer appear in the ``stores`` list in the image-show response.
I absolutely refuse to even hint that the expected usecase would be deliberate admin action rather than system failure like you make it sound.
IMO original wording makes sense to me

I assume you're joking.

If the problem is system failure, then we absolutely should not be deleting the location because when recovery occurs, the data will be there but the reference to it in Glance will not.

mariadb/templates/bin/_start.py.tpl.message: why not a random delay on startup so they end up staggered?

That could make the issue less likely to occur initially if the pods are all starting at the same time, but if we get unlucky (e.g. after killing a pod), then they will stay in sync. We would need the attempts offset by at least the duration of a successful end-to-end update of the grastate configmap (involving a separate read and write). If that is ~10ms, and we have three replicas, we would still have a ~0.3% chance of hitting the issue (any two or more replicas landing in the same 10ms slot). Worse if the update takes longer.

puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/ma.message: These are good comments and should be preserved in the template.

These could be defined inside the ERB as well. There's no reason to have this filename in the puppet manifest.

I would suggest using mktemp inside the ERB to create a unique file. Something like:

configmap_temp_file=$(mktemp /tmp/cluster_configmap_XXXX.yaml)
...
rm -f ${configmap_temp_file}

The mktemp would create an empty file with a unique filename, ensuring you're not colliding with an existing file.
