gerrit/projects.yaml.message: Why tripleo? The whole point of us not wanting it in tripleo-ansible is that this is a generic thing. If anything this could/should be ansible-role-ipa

> Maybe this is the point that was missed here.  The proposed code
 > did call tripleo-ansible.  It is the main way that we interface
 > with IPA.
 > 
 > Basically, the proposed code has the following elements:
 > 
 > 1. code to parse openstack specific data (server metadata)
 > that is generated by tripleo to turn it into a set of
 > services to be added to ipa.

Since this is tripleo specific, tripleo-ansible works for this.  This seems like something that would be a filter/plugin to go from one format into another.

 > 2. calls to ansible-freeipa to add those services.

Likely should be tripleo-ansible or in THT

 > 3. code  to search ipa for all the services associated with a
 > given host, and then to delete them (for node scale down
 > or for stack delete).

This seems like something that the ansible-freeipa would benefit from.

 > 4. code to create a user and set up all the privileges needed
 > to do the things opesnatck wants to do -- add hosts, add
 > services, add dns entries.
 > 

This seems like it should also be in ansible-freeipa or rather calls from tripleo-ansible into ansible-freeipa

 > There are parts which use python and ipa cli calls rather than
 > ansible-freeipa.  We'd rather not do that, but those are for places
 > where ansible-freeipa is not yet robust enough to do what we need
 > to do.  We're working with those folks to add the relevant features
 > but that will take time.  Over time, many of those bits will
 > simplify as the features get added.
 > 
 > (1) and (2) above seem to be things that according to what you said
 > above fit perfectly in tripleo-ipa.
 > 
 > (3) is also needed - but will be significantly simplified once the
 > relevant feature is added to ansible-freeipa
 > 
 > (4) is something that we could potentially add to tripleo-operator
 > as it is something that is supposed to be run to configure the ipa
 > server to have the right perms etc. for openstack work.

tripleo-operator-ansible is purely to wrap tripleocli related items. So unless you're planning on providing an openstackcli interface for them, that wouldn't make sense.

Alex, based on the how our conversation was going, it really sounded like we were re-evaluating the choice to host this outside of tripleo-ansible, and instead would go with the originally proposed patches given that most of the code was tripleo specific.

I commented on the original reviews to indicate which parts were tripleo specific and where ansible-freeipa was called.
Do we still want to create a new separate repo?

If we do, then we will likely refactor this into several roles - setup, service-registration, service-deregistration or something similar, so it would not be a single role.

We'll take whatever approach you want us to do - just let us know.

After reading, I'm fine naming it tripleo-ipa; if it has its own governance: you and the people who'll maintain it.
It's fair to say that tripleo-ansible has existing roles that don't do tripleo only things (dpdk, etc); but this isn't something we're willing to continue and I would rather have tripleo-ipa, maintained by security folks and integrated in tripleo by calling the roles from THT directly.

There is already an ansible-freeipa project ("Ansible roles and modules for FreeIPA"), which we will be using to interface with IPA.

tripleo-ipa will contain roles to prepare the undercloud for interfacing with ipa and register/unregister TripleO services in IPA.

The role that calls ansible-freeipa can live in tripleo-ansible. The original issue was that the original proposed code did not consume ansible-freeipa and we didn't want *that* to live in tripleo-ansible. The integration code that is specific to tripleo that calls ansible-freeipa can live in THT or tripleo-ansible.

My concern is that I don't want another tripleo-ipsec where we dump ansible bits that go unmaintained.  I'm not convinced this is the correct solution but rather one for expediency rather than correctness.

tripleo-ipa is going to be central to the way we do TLS everywhere - for pre-provisioned nodes and those created using nova.  Its also the way that we will do brownfield.

I expect that eventually most deploys will need to have tls everywhere for security requirements.  We have a strong vested interest in keeping this maintained and improving and simplifying it over time.

tripleo-ipsec did not have any real CI and tests.  the proposed code has real molecule tests that exercise all the things and will be exercised in tls everywhere deploys (fs39) as well as a new standalone tls gate that rlandy is developing.

There is code that is needed to go from tripleo to ipa that does tripleo specific things.  We can put all of it in THT and call it from there -- which I think is unwieldy and harder to maintain - or we can encapsulate much of it here.
I'll let Ade weigh in here.

Maybe this is the point that was missed here.  The proposed code did call tripleo-ansible.  It is the main way that we interface with IPA.

Basically, the proposed code has the following elements:

1. code to parse openstack specific data (server metadata)
   that is generated by tripleo to turn it into a set of 
   services to be added to ipa.
2. calls to ansible-freeipa to add those services.
3. code  to search ipa for all the services associated with a
   given host, and then to delete them (for node scale down 
   or for stack delete).
4. code to create a user and set up all the privileges needed
   to do the things opesnatck wants to do -- add hosts, add 
   services, add dns entries.

There are parts which use python and ipa cli calls rather than ansible-freeipa.  We'd rather not do that, but those are for places where ansible-freeipa is not yet robust enough to do what we need to do.  We're working with those folks to add the relevant features but that will take time.  Over time, many of those bits will simplify as the features get added.

(1) and (2) above seem to be things that according to what you said above fit perfectly in tripleo-ipa.

(3) is also needed - but will be significantly simplified once the relevant feature is added to ansible-freeipa

(4) is something that we could potentially add to tripleo-operator as it is something that is supposed to be run to configure the ipa server to have the right perms etc. for openstack work.
Is this going to be a role repository? If so can we rename it to ansible-role-tripleo-ipa instead?

Right now, 1 is implemented using a python script.  We can look into creating some kind of filter/ plugin instead.

3 is definitely something that would be useful in ansible-freeipa, and we'll work to get it there.  Right now, we implement that in python because ipa has a good python api.  We can simplify this considerably when the feature merges in freeipa-ansible

4 feels very tripleo specific to me in the sense that you are creating a user with the exact permissions to do the things that tripleo is goin g to need to do.  You don't have carte blanche admin access.  We currently implement this with a mixture of calls to ansible-freeipa to do the things we can, and cli calls to do the things we cannot.  Again - we're working to add the missing things to ansible-freeipa

neutron/conf/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/ovn.message:
What happens if ovn<2.12 and you use this parameter?

IMO, you need a sanity check. If igmp_snooping_enabled=True, then you should check that OVN=>2.12

Nothing really happens, the feature will not work and OVN will treat multicast as broadcast traffic.

In order to enable igmp snooping we need to set "mcast_snoop" on a field called "other_config" in the Logical_Switch table, this field is just a JSON blob. If OVN does not support it, the config will be ignored.

Checking for OVN 2.12 is not ideal due to backports. For example, OVN 2.11 offered by Red Hat does support IGMP but upstream OVN it's 2.12+

proliantutils/ilo/ipmi.py.message: The existing code was working earlier. What is the actual change which has caused this issue to surface?

Popen.communicate() returns ascii strings by default. In python2 default string encoding is 'ascii' but in python3 it is 'utf-8'. So far the testing was done on py2 hence, the issue was not seen before. At multiple places string operations are being performed on the output from Popen.communicate() which fail in python3 due to the encoding mismatch.

proliantutils/tests/ilo/ipmi_sample_outp.message: Why only one output needs to be encoded?

This constant is being used as mocked return value for Popen.communicate() which returns 'ascii' encoded strings by default. It would work fine in py2 but needs to be converted from 'utf-8' to 'ascii' in py3

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Primary and Site seem to represent the same thing, what about converging on Site since that is already pervasive within airship? For example CurrentContextSiteEntrypoint().

Also are we sure we want to force an explicit model for how sites are stored in repos? For example, what about something like this:

# for multiple sites per repo model
manifests:
  dummy:
    default-site-repository=sites
    repositories:
      sites: <multi site repo>
contexts:
  site_a:
    site-path=manifests/a
  site_b:
    site-path=manifests/b

# for single site per repo model
manifests:
  dummy:
    repositories:
      site_a: <site a repo>
      site_b: <site b repo>
contexts:
  site_a:
    site-repository: site_a
    site-path=manifests
  site_b:
    site-repository: site_b
    site-path=manifests

Higher level tooling could be used to automate around a particular site repo model desired within an organization.

pkg/config/testdata/config-string.yaml.message:
"primary" does not really tell me anything. doesn't this just represent which repo to find the "entrypoints" in?  what about:

entrypoint:
  repoository: primary # could rename this example repo to "sites" or similar
  path: manifests/site/test-site
repositories:
  primary: ...

or alternatively why not just allow each repository to specify the "path" of manifests we care about, and want to install to a particular directory. Then repositories can store their manifests at whatever path they desire, as opposed to needing to be at the top-level:

entrypoint-path: sites # could specify further subpath here if desired
repositories:
  sites:
    path: manifests/site/test-site
    auth:
      ssh-key: testdata/test-key.pem
      type: ssh-key
    checkout:
      branch: ""
      force: false
      remote-ref: ""
      tag: v1.0.1
    url: http://dummy.url.com/manifests.git
  globals:
    path: manifests
    ...

1) Yes, this can be valid object, just different implementation
2) This was previous patch set implementation, and it was decided , that path site-path, should belong to higher level object, as it only makes sense for primary repository.

pkg/config/types.go.message: Since these repos are site specific anyway, Why introduce the concept of site path and site name to derive it? Why not just expand Repositories with a much needed "SubPath" property, and for a site "A" expect them to specify a repository with Repo.SubPath = "manifests/site/a" - this functionality could also extend to extra repositories where users had global things not at the root of their repository but in some SubPath (which would require we extract the contents of SubPath into the TargetPath, vs the entire repo). I think of SubPath (or whatever is an appropriate name) meaning what directory within this repository do you want us to consider the "root" for this particular repo.  I think this is needed in general, not just for site.  I think we should strive for removing as much "autogenerated magic" as possible.

This seems very "PrimaryRepository" specific at least in terms of the comment.  If this is going to be a property for any Repository definition, I expect that it is the contents of *this* SubPath that are placed into target/repoName which to me is applicable to any repository where you may not want to work with the entire repo. I still think SubPath makes more sense here, as a "SitePath" is very Network Cloud or Treasuremap specific term.

pkg/document/pull/pull.go.message:
Originally, we said that we wanted the checkout pattern to be very consistent within TargetPath, namely:
  /targetPath/repo.foo.bar/
  /targetPath/repo.baz.boo/

With this change, the checkout paths would now be arbitrary, up to the name you associate with the repository.  While this offers more flexibility, it means when you want to design a document set that will reference across repositories that you expect airshipctl to "pull together", you need to have your airship configuration correctly aligned.  For instance, with the old way, you would require that people refer to other repos in kustomization.yaml's as:

  resources:
  - ../repo.foo.bar/someresource

but now, you would:

  resources:
  - ../someName/someresources

where someName needs to be aligned in both the configuration and in all the document sets, so without the "magic" airship config, pulling all this together wouldn't work.
will fix this, this appears to be a bug anyway, with current implementation we will stull pull into path.Join(currentManifest.TargetPath, name) + basename(URL)
